liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Earlier, we reported that Optus mobiles could still call emergency services. But now Optus says some customers can't. liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: I'm seeing some comments from people who are back online. But a bunch of you aren't. The latest post on the Optus Help X account (the social media platform formerly known as Twitter) says "some" services are fixed. But it might take a while. We don't have a concrete timeframe, but here's what the company says: "This may take a few hours for all services to recover, and different services may restore at different sites over that time."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Optus: Restoring full service 'may take a few hours'

"This may take a few hours for all services to recover, and different services may restore at different sites over that time."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Israel's military says it has located and destroyed more tunnels used by Hamas in northern Gaza, including one near an amusement park and another near a university. The IDF has published vision and a folder of photos appearing to show troops and bulldozers near Al Noor amusement park south of Gaza City. On Telegram, it said it located an underground tunnel running adjacent to the theme park and destroyed it. The folder of images also included a photo appearing to show soldiers and tanks in the vicinity of a different ferris wheel about 9 kilometres away. Map data analysed by the ABC indicates this ferris wheel is located near the Al Hilal (The Crescent) Sports Club, near the coast north of Gaza City. The IDF did not comment on what its soldiers were doing in this area in its Telegram post. In its update, it also said it had destroyed an "underground tunnel shaft and a weapons warehouse" containing chemicals and mines, found near a university, but the ABC could not identify the location from the provided vision. Earlier today the IDF said it was moving into the "heart of Gaza city". Both ferris wheels are located about 5km away from the city centre. The ABC could not independently verify when the IDF's photos were taken.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Hamas tunnel near Gaza theme park destroyed, IDF says

children.content: Israel's military says it has located and destroyed more tunnels used by Hamas in northern Gaza, including one near an amusement park and another near a university.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A total of 28 Australians have now managed to cross from Gaza to Egypt with the help of goverment officials, with most of them already back in Australia, a Department of Foreign Affairs spokesperson has told the ABC. A family of three Australian citizens crossed the border to Egypt through Rafah on November 7, the ABC has confirmed. Departures out of Gaza depend on "a range of factors", the spokesperson said, with a challenging situation on the ground changing rapidly. "The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade is assisting 76 individuals in Gaza, including Australians and their families, who have requested our help to depart", the DFAT said. "Australia is doing what we can to support those Australians and their families still in Gaza, including providing the best available information and options for their safety, and communicating through all available channels." The spokesperson said Australia was supporting international efforts to keep the Rafah border crossing open for humanitarian purposes and for civilians to pass through. Australians in need of emergency consular assistance should contact the Australian Government's 24-hour Consular Emergency Centre on +61 2 6261 3305 (from overseas) or 1300 555 135 (from within Australia).
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Another three Australians cross from Gaza to Egypt, bringing the total to 28, DFAT confirms

children.content: A total of 28 Australians have now managed to cross from Gaza to Egypt with the help of goverment officials, with most of them already back in Australia, a Department of Foreign Affairs spokesperson has told the ABC.
A family of three Australian citizens crossed the border to Egypt through Rafah on November 7, the ABC has confirmed.
Departures out of Gaza depend on "a range of factors", the spokesperson said, with a challenging situation on the ground changing rapidly.
"The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade is assisting 76 individuals in Gaza, including Australians and their families, who have requested our help to depart", the DFAT said.

"Australia is doing what we can to support those Australians and their families still in Gaza, including providing the best available information and options for their safety, and communicating through all available channels."
The spokesperson said Australia was supporting international efforts to keep the Rafah border crossing open for humanitarian purposes and for civilians to pass through.
Australians in need of emergency consular assistance should contact the Australian Government's 24-hour Consular Emergency Centre on
(from overseas) or
(from within Australia).

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: While Israel has been clear about its desire to eliminate Hamas, what remains less clear is who would assume responsibility for the Gaza Strip once the military operation ends. Yesterday Israeli PM Benjamin Netanyahu raised the prospect of Israel taking control of the administration of the Gaza Strip once Hamas is defeated. "Clearly Israel is going to have to exercise ultimate security control over the Gaza strip, because we saw what happened when we don't," Eylon Levy, spokesperson for the Israeli government, told Patricia Karvelas on RN Breakfast when asked to comment on Netanyahu's words. He said he could not go into detail on what "ultimate security control" would mean, but said the Gaza Strip would have to be demilitarised. The last 20 years since Israel withdrew its troops and settlers from the Gaza Strip were a "failed experiment", he said. When asked by about US officials' comments against an Israeli occupation of Gaza, Levy elaborated: "When we talk about ultimate security for the Gaza strip, we are not talking about Israeli soldiers necessarily patrolling inside and being there all the time. "We're going to need mechanisms and safeguards to ensure that the area is not taken over by terrorists the way that it has been over the last 20 years." Listen to the full interview on ABC RN Breakfast below.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israel wants to exercise 'ultimate security control' over Gaza after war, government spokesperson says

featuredLink.title: What happens to Gaza when the conflict ends? - ABC listen

children.content: While Israel has been clear about its desire to eliminate Hamas, what remains less clear is who would assume responsibility for the Gaza Strip once the military operation ends.

He said he could not go into detail on what "ultimate security control" would mean, but said the Gaza Strip would have to be demilitarised.
The last 20 years since Israel withdrew its troops and settlers from the Gaza Strip were a "failed experiment", he said.
When asked by about US officials' comments against an Israeli occupation of Gaza, Levy elaborated:
"When we talk about ultimate security for the Gaza strip, we are not talking about Israeli soldiers necessarily patrolling inside and being there all the time.
"We're going to need mechanisms and safeguards to ensure that the area is not taken over by terrorists the way that it has been over the last 20 years."
Listen to the full interview on ABC RN Breakfast below.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: PwC, the firm at the centre of the tax leaks scandal, has confirmed it is cutting 338 jobs from its Australian operations. In statement the firm said: "PwC Australia has today taken steps to adjust its workforce to address the divestment of its government business, a change in portfolio and strategic focus, as well as economic and business headwinds" It said the firm's leadership informed staff and partners of the changes today in Adelaide, where 141 roles will be impacted and made redundant. The PwC Australia's Skilled Service Hub (SSH) in Adelaide, where the 141 jobs are being lost, supports PwC's public sector and corporate clients. The majority of those impacted roles are in PwC's trust and risk, and consulting teams. The firm said the hub was opened in 2021 "in large part to support the firm's growing public sector business and the data sovereignty requirements of those clients, but in light of the Scyne divestment, the impact the past few months has had on our business, and broader market conditions, many of the workforce demands met by the delivery centre are no longer required". PwC Australia CEO Kevin Burrowes also said a further 197 roles would be made redundant across the firm's general national workforce, in response to "the reduction in the size of the business, the firm's changing portfolio and strategic areas of focus, and economic headwinds". Included in the redundancies are the 75 staff who were unable to join Scyne Advisory and put on leave last week. "We attempted to find alternative positions for these impacted staff within PwC, however, this was not always possible or desired by the individual given their client work, areas of expertise or skills," he said. "These are extremely difficult decisions and my thoughts are with all of those people and their families impacted by the changes we have been forced to make. "While we are optimistic about the future, PwC must take pragmatic action to manage these challenges and make difficult decisions to meet the needs of its clients and to ensure the long-term success of the firm." He added that other than a small number of Skills Service Hub Adelaide roles, PwC Australia is not making any audit team roles redundant. The firm also plans to transition 1,300 staff and 100 partners to Scyne Advisory, he said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: PwC announces 338 job losses as firm coms under pressure

children.content: PwC, the firm at the centre of the tax leaks scandal, has confirmed it is cutting 338 jobs from its Australian operations.

In statement the firm said: "PwC Australia has today taken steps to adjust its workforce to address the divestment of its government business, a change in portfolio and strategic focus, as well as economic and business headwinds"
It said the firm's leadership informed staff and partners of the changes today in Adelaide, where 141 roles will be impacted and made redundant.

The PwC Australia's Skilled Service Hub (SSH) in Adelaide, where the 141 jobs are being lost, supports PwC's public sector and corporate clients. The majority of those impacted roles are in PwC's trust and risk, and consulting teams.

The firm said the hub was opened in 2021 "in large part to support the firm's growing public sector business and the data sovereignty requirements of those clients, but in light of the Scyne divestment, the impact the past few months has had on our business, and broader market conditions, many of the workforce demands met by the delivery centre are no longer required".

props.alt: a man in a hiwte shirt smiling

children.content: PwC Australia CEO Kevin Burrowes says they are maing poeple redundant.
(Supplied. )

PwC Australia CEO Kevin Burrowes also said a further 197 roles would be made redundant across the firm's general national workforce, in response to "the reduction in the size of the business, the firm's changing portfolio and strategic areas of focus, and economic headwinds".
Included in the redundancies are the 75 staff who were unable to join Scyne Advisory and put on leave last week.

"We attempted to find alternative positions for these impacted staff within PwC, however, this was not always possible or desired by the individual given their client work, areas of expertise or skills," he said.
"These are extremely difficult decisions and my thoughts are with all of those people and their families impacted by the changes we have been forced to make.

"While we are optimistic about the future, PwC must take pragmatic action to manage these challenges and make difficult decisions to meet the needs of its clients and to ensure the long-term success of the firm."
He added that other than a small number of Skills Service Hub Adelaide roles, PwC Australia is not making any audit team roles redundant.
The firm also plans to transition 1,300 staff and 100 partners to Scyne Advisory, he said.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Commonwealth Bank says it is using artificial intelligence to help reduce technology-facilitated financial abuse in light of research showing 1 in 4 Australian adults have experienced financial abuse from their partner. The Australian bank said in a statement that it is making its artificial intelligence and machine learning techniques available for free, to any bank in the world. "The AI model helps to identify digital payment transactions that include harassing, threatening or offensive messages â referred to as technology-facilitated abuse," it said. CBA group customer advocate Angela MacMillan said the bank developed the technology "because we noticed that some customers were using transaction descriptions as a way to harass or threaten others". "Financial abuse occurs when money is used to gain control over a partner and is one of the most powerful ways to keep someone trapped in an abusive relationship," she said. "Sadly we see that perpetrators use all kinds of ways to circumvent existing measures such as using the messaging field to send offensive or threatening messages when making a digital transaction. "By using this model we can scan unusual transactional activity and identify patterns and instances deemed to be high risk so that the bank can investigate these and take action." The bank said the model detects around 1,500 high-risk cases annually. Read more about how domestic violence is a $2 billion business problem below.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: CBA says it's using AI to fight financial abuse

featuredLink.title: 'Your perpetrator can show up at your workplace': How domestic violence became a business problem

children.content: Commonwealth Bank says it is using artificial intelligence to help reduce technology-facilitated financial abuse in light of research showing 1 in 4 Australian adults have experienced financial abuse from their partner.
The Australian bank said in a statement that it is making its artificial intelligence and machine learning techniques available for free, to any bank in the world.
"The AI model helps to identify digital payment transactions that include harassing, threatening or offensive messages â referred to as technology-facilitated abuse," it said.
CBA group customer advocate Angela MacMillan said the bank developed the technology "because we noticed that some customers were using transaction descriptions as a way to harass or threaten others".
"Financial abuse occurs when money is used to gain control over a partner and is one of the most powerful ways to keep someone trapped in an abusive relationship," she said.
"Sadly we see that perpetrators use all kinds of ways to circumvent existing measures such as using the messaging field to send offensive or threatening messages when making a digital transaction.
"By using this model we can scan unusual transactional activity and identify patterns and instances deemed to be high risk so that the bank can investigate these and take action."
The bank said the model detects around 1,500 high-risk cases annually.
Read more about how domestic violence is a $2 billion business problem below.
